faqs.what is hypertension: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a condition where the force of the blood against your artery walls is consistently too high.
faqs.what are symptoms of high blood pressure: High blood pressure often has no noticeable symptoms, which is why it's called the 'silent killer'. Regular checkups are important.
faqs.how can I reduce my blood pressure: You can lower blood pressure through a healthy diet, regular exercise, reducing salt, avoiding alcohol and tobacco, and managing stress.
faqs.can hypertension be cured: Hypertension cannot be cured, but it can be managed effectively with lifestyle changes and medications.
faqs.what foods to avoid: Avoid salty, fatty, and processed foods. Reduce red meat, sugary snacks, and caffeine.

General Questions.what causes hypertension: Hypertension can be caused by genetics, obesity, lack of physical activity, high salt intake, stress, smoking, alcohol, or chronic conditions like diabetes and kidney disease.
General Questions.is hypertension common: Yes, hypertension is very common worldwide, especially among adults over the age of 40.
General Questions.is high blood pressure serious: Yes, if left untreated, it can lead to heart disease, stroke, kidney failure, and other serious health issues.

Medication & Monitoring.do I need medicine for hypertension: Many people need medication along with lifestyle changes to control high blood pressure. Always follow your doctor’s advice.
Medication & Monitoring.how often should I check my blood pressu: If diagnosed, check your blood pressure at least once a day or as recommended by your doctor.
Medication & Monitoring.can I stop taking BP medicine if I feel: No, never stop medication without consulting your doctor. Hypertension often has no symptoms.

Diet & Lifestyle.is coffee bad for high blood pressure: Caffeine can temporarily raise blood pressure. It's best to limit coffee intake if you have hypertension.
Diet & Lifestyle.is salt really that bad: Yes, high salt intake can raise your blood pressure. Choose low-sodium alternatives and limit processed foods.
Diet & Lifestyle.can I eat eggs with high blood pressure: Eggs in moderation are fine. Choose boiled or poached instead of fried, and avoid adding salt.

Exercise & Habits.can exercise help reduce blood pressure: Yes! Regular aerobic exercise like walking, cycling, or swimming helps lower and control blood pressure.
Exercise & Habits.how much sleep do I need: Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep per night. Poor sleep can raise blood pressure.
Exercise & Habits.does stress cause high blood pressure: Chronic stress may contribute to high blood pressure. Stress management is important for your health.

Support & Lifestyle.can I live a normal life with hypertensi: Absolutely! With proper management, most people with hypertension live full, active lives.
Support & Lifestyle.should I avoid traveling with high blood: Not necessarily. Just keep taking your meds, stay hydrated, and avoid stress or unhealthy food.

Hypertension Relief.how can I get relief from hypertension: You can relieve hypertension by maintaining a healthy diet, exercising regularly, reducing salt, avoiding stress, quitting smoking, and taking prescribed medications.
Hypertension Relief.what is the fastest way to lower blood p: Deep breathing, resting in a quiet place, and drinking water can help temporarily. But long-term control requires consistent lifestyle changes and medication if needed.
Hypertension Relief.what foods help lower blood pressure qui: Foods like bananas, leafy greens, beetroot, oats, garlic, and berries can help reduce blood pressure over time.
Hypertension Relief.can drinking water reduce blood pressure: Yes, staying hydrated helps regulate blood pressure, especially if dehydration is contributing to high BP.
Hypertension Relief.is yoga helpful for hypertension: Yes, yoga and meditation can help reduce stress and lower blood pressure when practiced regularly.
Hypertension Relief.can walking reduce high blood pressure: Yes, brisk walking for 30 minutes a day can significantly lower blood pressure over time.
Hypertension Relief.how to reduce high blood pressure natura: Reduce salt, eat fresh vegetables and fruits, avoid alcohol and smoking, exercise, manage stress, and get enough sleep.
Hypertension Relief.which home remedies work for hypertensio: Home remedies include garlic, hibiscus tea, flaxseed, and daily exercise. Always check with your doctor before trying new remedies.
Hypertension Relief.can breathing exercises lower blood pres: Yes, slow deep breathing can activate relaxation responses and lower blood pressure.
Hypertension Relief.how does sleep affect blood pressure: Poor sleep increases stress and blood pressure. Aim for 7-9 hours of restful sleep every night.

Doctor Advice.when should I see a doctor for high bloo: You should consult a doctor if your blood pressure stays consistently above 140/90 mmHg, or if you feel dizziness, headaches, chest pain, or vision problems.
Doctor Advice.what tests are done for hypertension: Common tests include blood pressure measurement, blood tests, urine tests, ECG, and sometimes kidney or heart scans.
Doctor Advice.can hypertension damage my body: Yes. Long-term hypertension can damage your heart, kidneys, eyes, and brain if not managed properly.

Hypertension in Children.can children have high blood pressure: Yes, children can have hypertension, especially if they're overweight, have kidney problems, or a family history of high BP.
Hypertension in Children.how to treat high blood pressure in chil: Treatment involves healthy eating, physical activity, limiting salt and screen time, and sometimes medications.

Stress & Mental Health.can stress cause high blood pressure: Yes, chronic stress can raise your blood pressure over time.
Stress & Mental Health.how to control stress to manage blood pr: Try meditation, deep breathing, talking to a therapist, walking outdoors, or listening to calming music.

BP Levels Explained.what is a normal blood pressure range: A normal range is usually around 120/80 mmHg. Above 140/90 mmHg is considered high.
BP Levels Explained.what is considered stage 1 or stage 2 hy: Stage 1 is 130-139/80-89 mmHg, and stage 2 is 140+/90+ mmHg. Talk to a doctor for proper diagnosis.

Healthy Foods.what are some BP-friendly meals: Try oatmeal with bananas, baked salmon with spinach, or boiled eggs with avocado toast — all low in salt and high in nutrients.
Healthy Foods.what drinks are good for high blood pres: Try hibiscus tea, beetroot juice, and coconut water. Avoid sugary drinks and limit caffeine.
